questions.correctAnswer: B) A complex number representing the amplitude and phase of a sinusoid
questions.explanation: A phasor is defined as a complex number V = Vm∠φ that captures the amplitude and phase of a sinusoid Vm·cos(ωt + φ). It does not include the time factor e^(jωt).

questions.prompt: What is the phasor representation of v(t) = 12cos(1000t + 45°)?
questions.explanation: To extract the phasor, take the amplitude (12) and phase (45°) from the cosine. The frequency (1000 rad/s) is NOT included in the phasor — it is implicit.

questions.prompt: Which property does the phasor domain use to represent differentiation?
questions.explanation: In the phasor domain, differentiating a sinusoid corresponds to multiplying its phasor by jω. This scales the amplitude by ω and shifts the phase by +90°.

questions.prompt: The phasor V = 20∠(-90°) at ω = 500 rad/s corresponds to which time-domain signal?
options: D) Both A and B are correct
questions.correctAnswer: D) Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: v(t) = 20cos(500t - 90°) is the direct conversion. Since cos(θ - 90°) = sin(θ), this equals 20sin(500t). Both expressions are equivalent.

questions.prompt: What information does a phasor NOT contain?
options: D) Whether it represents voltage or current
questions.explanation: A phasor contains amplitude and phase only. The frequency ω is implicit — it is the same for all signals in the circuit and is understood from context.

questions.prompt: If dv/dt has the phasor jωV, what does ∫v(t)dt correspond to in phasor domain?
questions.explanation: Integration is the inverse of differentiation. If d/dt ↔ jω, then ∫dt ↔ 1/(jω). So integrating v(t) corresponds to dividing its phasor by jω.

questions.prompt: On a phasor diagram, a phasor V = 10∠(-45°) would point in which direction?
options: A) 45° above the positive real axis
B) 45° below the positive real axis
C) Along the negative imaginary axis
D) Along the positive real axis
questions.correctAnswer: B) 45° below the positive real axis
questions.explanation: A negative phase angle means the phasor is measured clockwise from the positive real axis. -45° puts it 45° below the real axis, in the fourth quadrant.

questions.prompt: Which of the following is TRUE about v(t) vs its phasor V?
options: A) v(t) is complex; V is real
B) v(t) depends on time; V does not
C) v(t) contains phase; V does not
D) v(t) and V are interchangeable
questions.correctAnswer: B) v(t) depends on time; V does not
questions.explanation: v(t) is the instantaneous, time-varying, always-real signal. V is a time-independent complex number encoding amplitude and phase. v(t) is recovered via v(t) = Re{Ve^(jωt)}.
